review_title: Rewarding but Challenging – A Transformative Journey in the Realm of Research
pros: Abundant Research Opportunities: The University of Calgary offers a plethora of research projects across a variety of fields, providing ample opportunities for hands-on experience and in-depth learning. Mentorship from Renowned Academics: The chance to work directly with highly-regarded faculty members and seasoned researchers provides incredible opportunities for personal and professional growth. Multidisciplinary Approach: The university promotes multidisciplinary research which allows for broad learning and a chance to explore different fields of interest. Cutting-edge Facilities: The university boasts state-of-the-art research facilities, allowing assistants to use top-tier technology and equipment in their work.
cons: High Workload: Some research assistants have reported a demanding workload, which could lead to work-life balance issues. Competitive Environment: The competitive nature of research might be stressful to some individuals, especially those seeking a more relaxed work environment. Limited Career Advancement: As a research assistant, there might be limited opportunities for upward mobility within the university, depending on the department or project. Limited Funding: Depending on the specific project or department, there may be issues with securing adequate funding, which can impact the resources available to research assistants.

review_title: It is a job only done to survive

review_title: Unethically Poor pay with atrociously poor management
pros: Flexibility, purely speaking as a graduate researcher I set my schedule. But even that has it's downsides as it means that PIs feel empowered to schedule meetings at entirely inappropriate times, and vacation time is... not actually respected.
cons: The pay is only legal thanks to financial tom foolery by taking advantage of their position to not "Pay" people at all. You know you're working somewhere wonderful where talk of simply recognizing statutory holidays is laughed at and rejected as costing money... And they refuse to actually allow meeting minutes. Seriously you know you're the villain when you refuse to let the record show what you say. The truth is the landscape is changing and I wouldn't recommend anyone go to graduate "School". Trying to raise a conflict of interest concern and the people in power showing such a lack of understanding of the concept of conflict of interest that they don't even do the level of work they are supposed to do on paper.

review_title: If you scratch the facade of the University's employment standards, there will be rust underneath.
pros: Wonderful colleagues, convenient location, always glued in to latest research, and staff lunch and learns are nice (if ineffective to implement). Tuition support is the single greatest benefit the university offers, as well as $750 in flexible health or wellness spending.
cons: Extremely difficult to move up in pay, challenging to move laterally within the university, and  impossible to get a raise. If you start at the bottom it will take you 16+ years to get to what the position should pay. Depending on the position, you could be pressured to work at 110%, work overtime "off the books", but be incredibly underpaid for the work quality and output. Many University hiring committees also lie about not being able to give more than a 3% raise for internal hires due to the union agreement, which is false, so it just leaves many unhappy employees struggling to feel motivated in their work, underpaid and overworked. Burnout is real, so if you are one of the lucky ones, then you might have the time and energy to take advantage of tuition support. For most of the staff I know, it's fairly moot.

review_title: You have to suffer for everything
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Calgary, AB
pros: Individual people are generally nice in individual interactions.
cons:
U of C makes you work for everything you need or want, and makes it as complicated and painful of a process as possible. This applies to everything from just getting access to a building to getting funding or figuring out what the process is for having committee meetings. In part, this is because the websites are absolutely terrible, being difficult to navigate and not having the information one needs, plus the links don't work half the time or they take you to outdated documents. 

In addition, one gets the feeling as a grad student/TA that you're neither valued nor respected by the administration. You're constantly having to ask permission to do things (or, as an example, you must wait outside of the lab room for someone to go and open the door for you before you TA, because they don't trust you enough to give you access to it), people don't tell you what you need to know when you need to know it, you have to constantly nag some people to do things they said would get done weeks or months ago, etc. Overall, it feels like the administration doesn't care about their graduate students/TAs, it makes very little effort to improve things, and it only cares about protecting itself. 

Given that the pay is quite low, and the benefits are nearly worthless (For example, most of what you need/want is covered by the alberta health care system, and the university's health insurance doesn't cover most of the things that the alberta health care covers), I would strongly advice anyone against going to the U of C. There are much better universities out there.

review_title: Great benefits but management salaries aren't competitive - few salary increases except for unionized staff and faculty.
pros: There are excellent flexible medical benefits as well as education benefits for the employee and family members.  Staff receive a higher than average amount of vacation days (15 to start for unionized staff and 20 for management) plus other flexible days.  The organization is closed between Christmas and New Years - employees don't have to use their vacation allotment in order to get this time off.  For the most part, work-life balance is well supported by leadership.
cons: Salaries are not competitive, particularly for management staff (non-union and non-faculty).  Rewards and recognition are sparse and the performance evaluation system is poorly designed and executed.  It is supposed to be tied to "pay for performance"; however, the management group rarely sees salary increases and the results of evaluations can be skewed in order to avoid increasing compensation.  Spending is not as transparent as senior leadership would have staff and the public believe, and although accountability has been promoted as a priority, it doesn't seem to be as holistic as intended.

review_title: Job Security and not much else
pros:
Tuition benefits
Hard to get fired
Contract mandated raises
cons:
-Working with people that should have been fired
-Working under managers that were hired based on seniority not skills
-Department heads are academic appointments with little incentive to develop or retain staff
-No ability to negotiate raises based on work. The person down the hall might be making more and doing significantly less (or nap at their desk)
-Pay union dues, but the union does nothing for you unless you're being severely harassed
-Poor benefits package (only pay $30 per paramedical treatment, still paid over $100 out of pocket at last routine dentist visit, no vision)
-Hard to move laterally or up payscales
-Negotiate a higher salary for your first position because you'll only go up in tiny increments for the rest of your career
-High mandatory pension contributions ($200+ per paycheque)
-No professional development opportunities / career assistance

review_title: Awesome people and freedom, not enough money
pros:
People: The professors and the other graduate students I work with are great.  They are all respected in their fields and highly knowledgeable.

Freedom: I have lots of freedom to research the stuff I'm interested in.  No one is micro-managing my time.  I can balance my academic and personal life the way I want.  Awesome.
cons:
Money: Graduate students don't get paid very much.  The money you get as a graduate student isn't enough to live on in Calgary, unless you want to live in a *very* crappy basement apartment.  I'm constantly seeking additional sources of income, which is why I'm on this site.

Equipment: My research would benefit from some better equipment, but money seems to be tight so its difficult to get.  To clarify, I'm not talking about some $5 million particle accelerator or anything.  I'm just talking about a new desktop PC.

review_title: Great employer, but culture depends on the area/dept
pros: University of Calgary is a great place to work, great salary and benefits, flexible management - similar to other public sector workplaces.  If you're sick, don't come into work, that's dumb!  Stay home - if you really need to get something done, work from home.  In my dept (Haskayne) I worked in several positions and all were great experiences.
cons: I've heard from friends that work in other areas - ie: Engineering advisors office - where everyone is expected to work overtime everyday.  At Haskayne, we got our work done and went home on time, because they don't want to burn people out and they don't want to pay overtime!  So if you're applying for a job at the University of Calgary and you want to find out how the job is, look for someone that worked in that faculty/department to see if it's any good.  Some are really, really great, and some are absolute shite.

pros:
Flexible schedule. You can start early and finish early and your manager won't ever ask you to stay late. If he/she does, you will be notified in advance.

4 weeks vacation  (including about 5 days during Christmas)

Most of the staff is very cool to work with!

If you like the public sector, you will love uofc!

Lots of opportunities within Central Marketing.

Pension matched 100%.

Good raise if you are AUPE.
cons:
When you work for a faculty, you feel a little bit excluded from Central Marketing. They try to involve you but they clearly don't want to share many things with faculties which is understandable e I guess? 

The stupid pension plan takes 17% off your salary each month!!! When you are older it's great, not so much when you are young!

Everything is slow-paced. People will complain how much they have to do but let's be honest... it's super slow-paced! 

Don't assume you are gonna keep your job until retirement, they lay off many people from different reasons.

Benefits could be better.

If you are ambitious and like the challenge, this place is not for you!

They don't seem open to remote working.

review_title: University has taken a turn for the worse in recent years
pros:
-decent benefits package for FT and PT-regular employees
-percentage premium in lieu of benefits for PT-recurring employees is also pretty good
cons:
-HR is heavily biased towards management in any dispute, no matter how strong the employee's case is
-Union will not fight for you unless the University very clearly breached the Collective Bargaining Agreement
-Bizarre budgeting, such that several very costly construction projects completed in recent years, and some still ongoing, are just fine with President and Board, but University is not currently willing to give employees an annual raise at minimum equal to inflation for the next two years
-hours will be repeatedly and arbitrarily cut for PT employees with no explanation given. HR and AUPE union do nothing.

pros:
Well it was a 10 hour per week tutoring job. It allows students to develop their presenting skills, and share their knowledge with others. They offer help when you need it, and in that sense it was good.

The pay was good considering other part time job alternatives
cons: It really doesn't come down to education here, it's all about the money. Quite unfortunate, but it is the reality, so for what I did, it wasn't about helping the students learn the material, but rather prepare them for finals.

pros: UofC is pretty bad on the administrative side, they prize marks over everything; including actual experience and thus inflate the value of grades compared to the actual work space. The computer science and computer physics courses are behind date and do not give you a full education; as these courses are usually test based and not application based. As such the stress is not really worth it. Some positives is the UofC is a nice cheap and gives a good shot at most jobs provided your GPA is high enough to get recommended to those jobs.
cons: Supervisors are tricky per usual, but for research be very careful for the right supervisor, getting the wrong one will literally stop any project you have dead in your tracks

review_title: Great for those looking for work-life balance, friendly people, and competitive salaries
pros:
-Great flexibility and benefits
-Friendly people
-Lots of parking available
-Defined benefit pension plan
Overall, The U of C is a great place to work, especially if you are a parent, or someone who is just looking for better work-life balance (relative to positions in downtown Calgary). If you live in NW Calgary, the commute is very fast relative to trying to fight through the rush-hour traffic to get downtown.
cons:
-Constant change causes one to wonder where they will be next
-Flexibility is good, but also depends on your manager
-lots of politics
The organization has a lot change taking place right now, so for some the "consistency" factor can make things a bit uneasy.  Of course, there are politics one must deal with  (but that is anywhere).

pros: It's a great city to live in, the University has a strong commitment to becoming a high ranking research institution and is taking measures to support innovative research.
cons: Some disciplines don't fit the research platform very well and are forced to merge/cast aside. Impacts on undergraduate education unfortunate with bigger class sizes, little reward for professors who dedicate extra time to teaching. I look forward to getting out of academia, this career track for new/young researchers is a road of many personal sacrifices, and few rewards.

pros: I like the way that they manage time. I had some flexibility in when to go to work which was good. On the other hand, they applied result-based management approach and they are quite patience in evaluation your performance.
cons: The problem is the low compensation package. No performance review nor consideration of salary increase unless you push it. Many layers in supervising and managing which was confused. Issues happened within your team other than reports and deadlines were left hanging and unsolved for a prolong period. Meanwhile, you are not empowered or delegate to make a decision which is frustrated

review_title: The vision for postdocs is not to turn them into faculty
pros: The University is keen on obtaining funding and supporting postdocs and PIs to obtain funding.
cons: There are no common standards or expectations for what a postdoc supervisor should do or provide. If your supervisor supports you in getting to the next stage of an academic career, you are lucky. The University hosts seminars encouraging postdocs to think about non-academic careers. They do not want postdocs to stay on as faculty once they finish. They want cheap labour to help produce more publications and get grant funding.

pros: The University is one of the largest employers in Calgary. They have a very good benefits package and often opportunities for internal lateral movement.
cons: Two of the three managers I had during my several years at the University were some of the worst I had. There is little interest in the employee's experience, but a huge focus on the employee's contributions to the organization. My concerns, when voiced, were ignored. To be successful, managers need only dedicate most of their time to managing up and maintaining appearances. Too bad, there are lots of good people working there. Many choose to stay in the union jobs because so many people in management roles are fired.

review_title: My experience at the University of Calgary was very nice, but was diminished greatly by the lack of competitive wages.
pros: The University of Calgary was a very nice place to work for various reasons, including flexible hours, great staff, and the ability to drive your own research.
cons: The University of Calgary was a very nice place to work, however the experience was diminished (and I won't be going back again) due to the lack of competitive wages and benefits.

pros: Ascendent University with ambitious goals and a clear plan to get there. Emphasis on work life balance and an interest in the happiness of the Univ. employees.

pros: I enjoyed everyday I worked there, primarily because of the position I had as Student Ombudsperson. Helping students was the best thing about it.
cons: Politics. Position was funded by University, Grad Students and Student Union. I moved offices 4 times in 20 months and had three bosses in the first 12 months. In the end the Student Union torpedoed my job by threatening to withdraw funding. A  elected Student thought she was my 'boss' even though she never met with me and I never met the SU executive...petty student. I loved working there..not so much the politics.

job_title: Residence Life Coordinator in Calgary, AB
pros: There are truly no pros.
cons:
I experienced a closed culture of dissatisfaction and a terrible work environment.
- Management implemented a significant overall reduction in net pay due to mandatory live-in situation with only 1 week notice to staff - staff were strained financially due to this change and some left the position as a result.
- Management purposely did not fill a vacant position, leading to significantly more work for staff and a 24-hour On Call schedule with frequency that I felt was damaging to staff's mental and physical well-being.
- At one point staff did work for approx. 21 days straight (usually 10 hour days) with no days off in between, because it was deemed that staff training required this. No overtime pay was awarded.
- Management was unsympathetic to serious mental health concerns and issues of staff that occurred as a direct result of the work in the Residence Life Coordinator position
- Salary levels for RLC position are significantly lower than industry average and approx $15,000 per annum lower than University of Alberta.
- Liability is extremely important to management, while welfare of staff, and the true "residence experience", do not appear to be core values in practice. In my experience, staff experiencing mental health issues are isolated and made to feel guilty.
- Rental rates are high overall and most are not competitive with the local market currently.
- In my experience, innovative ideas are often struck down in favour of doing things the way they have always been done.
- Sadly, from a student perspective, residence at the University of Calgary has become a shadow of what it once was -  you will be overwhelmed by the number of rules surrounding your time there, the unhelpfulness of staff, the lack of innovation and enthusiasm from management, and overall, the high price point for value - something really needs to change.
Due to my poor experience, I would not recommend working here, sadly. :(

review_title: Do not work for the Cumming School of Medicine
pros: Shorter work hours (830-4), not bad benefits and good pension, free education
cons:
CSM is an absolutely toxic, demoralizing place to work. 
The last couple of years I have noted in several departments:
-a destructive relationship between unionized employees and management 
-Directors who have no time or patience to keep managers in check 
-Management exploitation and downright abuse of employees not limited to: excluding people from meetings, punishments such as taking away projects and micromanaging, not being compensated for overtime, meals, or mileage, playing favourites, sabotaging careers, discouraging growth, manipulation, bullying, insults, gossip, frequent lying, and no communication on a basic level. 
-No culture. There are no gatherings. There is no pride. There is no morale or camaraderie, due to poor management. 
-No flexibility.Want to walk at lunch and work a little later? Too bad. You’re not a trusted adult. Need to see a doctor? Take 20 minutes to navigate Peoplesoft to claim every minute of your day. 
-The U of C claims to care about your mental and physical health. They don’t. There is no place to rest at foothills and nowhere to go with a problem.  If you are not well, get ready for a humiliating process to prove it, no matter how good you are at your job. Your value does not matter. How you fit into their box does. 
-Want to take more on your plate and grow? Sorry, you’ll enter a different pay bracket. High achievers are punished. 
-if you still want to work there, bring a lunch, or else you’ll be paying sky high prices for hospital food and will have no other options.
